title: Sandhyakanduri
text:
HELLO!!
I am Sandhya Kanduri!, I’m a graduate student currently pursuing a master’s degree in Data Analytics Engineering at George Mason University. I hold a bachelor’s degree in Computer Science Engineering, and throughout my academic journey, I’ve gained my skills in machine learning, data analysis, and problem-solving.
I have always had a passion for diving deep into data and uncovering the stories behind the numbers. Over the years, I’ve completed several internships, both technical and non-technical, which have broadened my understanding of various domains and enhanced my adaptability. I led two major projects focused on machine learning and data analysis, gaining hands-on experience with practical, real-world data challenges.
In addition to my technical background, I’m an active speaker who loves collaborating with others, and I’m known for my strong communication skills. I also had the opportunity to lead a student event club during my undergraduate years, where I organized a wide range of cultural and tech events, bringing together creative minds to make impactful experiences.

title: About
text: Welcome to my professional space! I’m Sandhya, currently pursuing a master’s degree in Data Analytics Engineering. With a strong foundation in Computer Science Engineering, I specialize in extracting insights from data, building predictive models, and driving data-driven solutions.

title: PROJECT 1
text: The visualized map that we took as a reference is intended to visually explore the best-paying job in each state and territory of the United States, providing geographical context for salary trends and highlighting what those top occupations are. It can serve as a reference for one’s decisions regarding career prospects or job opportunities based on location and salary potential. This is quite rightly the best way of capturing the dataset, since a median figure separates the sample between higher and lower half. All things being equal, someone working in each job will likely earn somewhere close to the numbers on the map.

title: PROJECT 1
text: This is an embedded PDF of Project 1.

title: PROJECT 1
text: The visualized map that we took as a reference is intended to visually explore the best-paying job in each state and territory of the United States, providing geographical context for salary trends and highlighting what those top occupations are. It can serve as a reference for one’s decisions regarding career prospects or job opportunities based on location and salary potential. This is quite rightly the best way of capturing the dataset, since a median figure separates the sample between higher and lower half. All things being equal, someone working in each job will likely earn somewhere close to the numbers on the map.

title: Codework
text:
# Set CRAN mirror
options(repos = c(CRAN = "https://cloud.r-project.org"))

# Assuming your data is in a data frame called 'df'
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

Occupation <- read.csv("/Users/sandhyakanduri/Desktop/stat_db.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
colnames(Occupation)

[1] "X"   "X.1" "X.2" "X.3" "X.4" "X.5"

colnames(Occupation) <- c("X", "AREA", "AREA_TITLE", "OCC_TITLE", "TOT_EMP", "A_MEDIAN")

Occupation <- Occupation[-1, ]

Occupation <- Occupation %>% select(-X)

Occupation$TOT_EMP <- as.numeric(gsub(",", "", Occupation$TOT_EMP))
Occupation$A_MEDIAN <- as.numeric(gsub(",", "", Occupation$A_MEDIAN))


#1. Bar Plot: Highest-Paid Occupations
#This bar plot will display the top 10 occupations by median wage.

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyverse)
install.packages("plotly")


The downloaded binary packages are in
    /var/folders/6m/42q07yxd7hn2y7bg5r_687dw0000gn/T//RtmpXR6RBd/downloaded_packages

library(plotly)


Attaching package: 'plotly'


The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2':

    last_plot


The following object is masked from 'package:stats':

    filter


The following object is masked from 'package:graphics':

    layout

# Get top 10 highest-paid occupations
top_occupations <- Occupation %>%
  arrange(desc(A_MEDIAN)) %>%
  top_n(10, A_MEDIAN)

# Create the plot using plot_ly
plot1 <- plot_ly(
  top_occupations,
  x = ~reorder(OCC_TITLE, A_MEDIAN),
  y = ~A_MEDIAN,
  type = 'bar',
  color = ~AREA_TITLE,  # This assigns different colors to each state
  colors = 'Set1'  # Using a color palette for distinction
) %>%
  layout(
    title = 'Top 10 Highest-Paid Occupations',
    xaxis = list(title = 'Occupation'),
    yaxis = list(title = 'Median Annual Wage'),
    margin = list(l = 100),
    showlegend = TRUE  # Enable the legend
  )

# Display the plot
plot1

# 2 Get top 10 occupations by total employment
top_emp_occupations <- Occupation %>%
  arrange(desc(TOT_EMP)) %>%
  top_n(10, TOT_EMP)

# Create the plot using plot_ly
plot2 <- plot_ly(
  top_emp_occupations,
  x = ~reorder(OCC_TITLE, TOT_EMP),
  y = ~TOT_EMP,
  type = 'bar',
  marker = list(color = 'Set2')
) %>%
  layout(
    title = 'Top 10 Occupations by Total Employment',
    xaxis = list(title = 'Occupation'),
    yaxis = list(title = 'Total Employment'),
    margin = list(l = 100), # Add margin for long occupation names
    showlegend = TRUE
  )

# Display the plot
plot2






#3. Geographical Distribution of Median Wages by Area

# Ensure AREA_TITLE is lowercased for matching
install.packages("maps")


The downloaded binary packages are in
    /var/folders/6m/42q07yxd7hn2y7bg5r_687dw0000gn/T//RtmpXR6RBd/downloaded_packages

library(maps)


Attaching package: 'maps'


The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    map

library(dplyr)

library(plotly)
library(datasets)

# Check the Occupation dataset structure and ensure A_MEDIAN is present and valid
str(Occupation)  # Look for A_MEDIAN and AREA_TITLE

'data.frame':   53 obs. of  5 variables:
 $ AREA      : chr  "1" "2" "4" "5" ...
 $ AREA_TITLE: chr  "Alabama" "Alaska" "Arizona" "Arkansas" ...
 $ OCC_TITLE : chr  "Psychiatrists" "Chief Executives" "Family Medicine Physicians" "Natural Sciences Managers" ...
 $ TOT_EMP   : num  40 80 1750 60 30 100 70 270 90 180 ...
 $ A_MEDIAN  : num  203570 206300 206950 206520 207780 ...

# Check for missing or identical values in A_MEDIAN
summary(Occupation$A_MEDIAN)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
 172700  205770  206750  205553  207420  207980 

# Map full state names to abbreviations
state_abbreviations <- data.frame(
  state = tolower(state.name),  # Ensure lowercase matching
  abbreviation = state.abb
)

# Ensure AREA_TITLE is in lowercase to match the state names
Occupations_cleaned <- Occupation %>%
  mutate(AREA_TITLE = tolower(AREA_TITLE)) %>%
  left_join(state_abbreviations, by = c("AREA_TITLE" = "state"))

# Summarize the median wage by area (state abbreviations)
state_wages <- Occupations_cleaned %>%
  group_by(abbreviation) %>%
  summarize(median_wage = mean(A_MEDIAN, na.rm = TRUE))

# Double-check the merged data
print(state_wages)

# A tibble: 51 × 2
   abbreviation median_wage
   <chr>              <dbl>
 1 AK                206300
 2 AL                203570
 3 AR                206520
 4 AZ                206950
 5 CA                207780
 6 CO                207590
 7 CT                206370
 8 DE                206480
 9 FL                206770
10 GA                207400
# ℹ 41 more rows

# Plot the choropleth map using state abbreviations
plot3 <- plot_ly(
  state_wages,
  type = 'choropleth',
  locations = ~abbreviation,  # Use state abbreviations
  locationmode = 'USA-states',
  z = ~median_wage,  # Median wage values should vary
  colorscale = 'Viridis',  # Color scale for clear visualization
  marker = list(line = list(color = 'white', width = 2)),  # Add borders for states
  colorbar = list(title = "Median Wage", ticksuffix = "$")  # Adjust color bar settings
) %>%
  layout(
    title = 'Geographical Distribution of Median Wages by State',
    geo = list(
      scope = 'usa',  # Focus on USA
      projection = list(type = 'albers usa'),  # Use Albers projection
      showlakes = TRUE,  # Show lakes
      lakecolor = 'rgb(255, 255, 255)'  # Color lakes white
    )
  )

# Display the plot
plot3






#4. Scatter Plot: Total Employment vs. Median Wage

# Create a stacked bar chart for total employment and median wage by occupation
library(plotly)



# Create a stacked bar chart for total employment and median wage by occupation
library(plotly)

# Create a scatter plot for total employment vs median wage by occupation with color
scatter_plot_colored <- plot_ly(
  Occupation,
  x = ~TOT_EMP,  # Total Employment on the x-axis
  y = ~A_MEDIAN,  # Median Wage on the y-axis
  type = 'scatter',
  mode = 'markers',
  marker = list(
    size = 8, 
    opacity = 0.6, 
    line = list(width = 1, color = 'black'),  # Clear markers with black border
    color = ~A_MEDIAN,  # Color the markers based on median wage
    colorscale = 'Viridis',  # Change color scale
    colorbar = list(title = 'Median Wage', thickness = 15)  # Add color bar
  ),
  text = ~paste("Occupation: ", OCC_TITLE, 
                "<br>Employment: ", formatC(TOT_EMP, format = "d", big.mark = ","),
                "<br>Median Wage: $", formatC(A_MEDIAN, format = "f", big.mark = ","))  # Text on hover
) %>%
  layout(
    title = list(
      text = 'Total Employment vs. Median Wage by Occupation',
      x = 0.5,
      font = list(size = 18)  # Increased font size for title
    ),
    xaxis = list(
      title = 'Total Employment',
      titlefont = list(size = 14),  # Larger x-axis title
      tickfont = list(size = 12),  # Increased tick label font size
      showgrid = TRUE  # Add grid lines for better readability
    ),
    yaxis = list(
      title = 'Median Wage',
      titlefont = list(size = 14),  # Larger y-axis title
      tickfont = list(size = 12),  # Increased tick label font size
      showgrid = TRUE  # Add grid lines for better readability
    ),
    height = 600,  # Height of the plot for better visualization
    margin = list(l = 50, r = 50, t = 50, b = 50)  # Adjust margins for clarity
  )

Warning: Specifying width/height in layout() is now deprecated.
Please specify in ggplotly() or plot_ly()

# Display the scatter plot
scatter_plot_colored

title: PROJECT 1
text:
Redesigned Graphs

Bar plot of the highest-paid occupations: This will show the top-paying occupations in descending order, highlighting the one with the highest median wage.


Graph useful to compare and contrast wages among the highest paid jobs include health-related jobs such as Psychiatrists, Nurse Anesthetists, Dentists, and Pediatricians and top management jobs including Chief Executives and Human Resources Managers.
They seem closer to, or well above, $200,000 for all occupations, which may be considered a high-paying employment.The vertical lines indicate the remuneration for these careers which vary in minor amounts,and this may be indicative of similar levels of remuneration across high-end segments of professions across different regions.
2.Bar plot of total employment by occupation: This will show the total number of employees in each occupation for better understanding of occupation distribution across the dataset.

Each bar gives the total amount of employees in that occupation. Family Medicine Physicians are the most, with over 3,000, while other occupations like Pediatricians and Dentists fall to around 800 and are much lower, though comparable to each other.
The family medicine physician has the highest total rate of employment, which shows that this occupation is in great demand compared to other occupations. They are serving almost 4 times as large as a workforce compared to occupations such as Chief Executives or Obstetricians. Lower Employment for Specialized Occupations: Jobs like Nurse Anesthetists,Obstetricians, and Chief Executives have low total employment because those occupations are specialized, and the number of roles is limited.
3.Geographical distribution of median wages by area: A map plot (choropleth map) to show median wages across different states or regions. color scale ranges from yellow to blue. Yellow indicates that the median is closer to $200k and blue represents wages over $205k.

Below is the map where states are colored by the median wages of occupations. Lighter colors indicate low wages, while darker colors indicate higher wages. It also shows that some states, colored in shades of blue and green, include Colorado, Nevada, and New York; this would indicate that the three states’ median wages are higher, closer to and above $205k.Pairs of states, including Wyoming and Alabama, show yellow, indicating lower median wages in the $200k range.
Colorado, California, Nevada, New York, and parts of the Northeast have had higher median wages than other areas. States at a low range include Alabama, Kentucky, Dakotas, etc. Most of the country demonstrates wages relatively similarly within a range from $200,000 to $205,000, which shows that wages do vary, although the range is narrow across most states. This map is a good way for users to comprehend how geography could affect the pay and should prove helpful for anyone looking to relocate in search of greater pay, or in compiling competitive wages state by state.This visualization also shows regional economic disparities, with some states offering much higher wages than others, possibly due to localized demand for specialized occupations.
4.Scatter plot of total employment vs. median wage: This will help identify any correlation between the size of employment and median wage for different occupations.

A gradient ranging from purple to yellow: yellow for higher wages above $205k and purple for the lower bound closer to $175k. Most of the observations are concentrated between $200k to $210k median wage, while the total employment usually stays below 600. While the count of job employment varies greatly for a few occupations, with numbers reaching up to 1800 employees, their median wages remain relatively related to the low-employment-level wages.
This scatter plot will help the user understand the development or otherwise of the association between how many people are employed in certain high-paying jobs and the wages they earn. It would probably yield a useful context to job seekers or professionals in these industries while comparing roles.
References:

HowMuch.net. (2020). The Best-Paying Occupation in Each State. Retrieved from https://howmuch.net/articles/best-paying-occupation-in-each-state.
Wickham, H. (2023). ggplot2: Create Elegant Data Visualisations Using the Grammar of Graphics. https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_bar.html
Hahn, N. (2023). Making Maps with R: Using ggplot2 for Mapping. Retrieved from https://bookdown.org/nicohahn/making_maps_with_r5/docs/ggplot2.html.
Wickham, H., Chang, W., Henry, L., et al. (2023). geom_point function reference. Retrieved from https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_point.html.
